Posts.Content: Oct 7, 2011 11:45PM mdg wrote: I just wanted to answer your questions about the Cold Caps.  They worked for me.  I did have my hair thin and I shed a lot of hair, but I still have a full head of hair.  My hair is down to the middle of my back.  It was manageable for me to do the caps as my med onc office had a freezer and caps already there and available for use.  YOu do have to pay for them and cold caps are not cheap but it was worth it for me.  My son was 4 when I was diagnosed.  He does not know the word cancer or chemo...he knows I had surgeries and knows I needed some strong medicines that sometimes made me tired.  I plan to tell him everything when he is older.  He never really saw me very sick and that was important to me.  Chemo was manageable for me.  Everyone is different.  I managed to exercise daily (5 days a week) through chemo and never missed a workout except infusion days. I got up every morning and got my son off to preschool too...never missed a morning all through chemo.  I cooked dinner every night.  I had a few days where I was not feeling great, but I never even had to take one pill for nasuea other than what they gave me on infusion day.   I am not advocating chemo, I am just sharing my experience.  I did have some side effects...for me the worst was the skin rash that lasted 3 mo's.  It was awful!  I had burning, itchy hive like skin for months.  It finally went away in July eventhough I finished chemo in May.  I knew for me that I could not sleep at night knowing I passed up the chemo...especially since my son is so young.  I know there are no guarantees but I know I did everything I could.  I don't want any regret....  Oh and you can see photos of my hair on my blog.  I posted a few weeks ago.  I usually wear my hair blown out straight but with cold caps you have to air dry.  It looks frizzy, wavy and shorter because of air drying.  My hair is down to the bra line on my back now that I wear it straight again.  I cut off 3 inches after chemo...my hair continued to grow all through chemo.  If you have any other quesions, PM me.  I don't mind.  Good luck with your decision. I am also on tamoxifen.  I started that in June.

Posts.Title: Scared to death and back to reality Dawn1008 Dawn1008

Posts.Content: Nov 19, 2012 12:56AM mdg wrote: I really did not bring much for the hospital as I was too out of it to care.  I did bring my Ipod to wear until surgery with soothing, relaxation music as I was pretty freaked.  That helped keep me calm.  I did also wear it a bit after surgery at night to help relax me.  I did not pack any pajamas or robe. I only brought a comfy sweat suit to wear home with a zip up jacket.   I brought an elastic headband to get my hair out of my face (I had long hair).  I brought some mints (in case I could not brush teeth) and some mouth wash.  I had a photo of my son and when I got freaked I just stayed focused on how I have to do this for him.  I did bring lots of pillows for the ride home and a blanket instead of a winter coat as I knew I could not get in/out of that post surgery.  I also brought a bucket and wipes for the car (I get sick from anesthesia) in case I got sick.  I don't think I brought much else.  I had drains.  I needed gauze, alcohol wipes, antibiotic cream and some tape for dealing with those.  I did also come home in a cami provided by the hospital that had drain holders.  I did use a shoelace and large safety pins to hold drains up while I bathed a bit.  I took some baths from the waist down the first several days before I could shower.  I can't remember anything else.  At home I did have a few pairs of button up pajamas and sweats.  I wore the cami most of the time and had DH wash it for me.  When I didn't have it on, I had on a hoodie with pockets and put the drains in the pockets.  After I got drains out, I mostly wore tank tops with anything that buttoned or zipped up over it.  The tanks with a shelf bra worked well as they are super stretchy and I just stepped into them and pulled them up instead of putting them over my head. Sorry but you won't be sleeping on your side anytime soon :(  A wedge pillow, body pillow and lots of extra pillows kept my as comfortable as possible so I could sleep.  OH and the pain meds cause constipation!  I never had this problem before and it was the WORST part of my surgery!   Start on stool softeners/laxitives immediately after surgery.  I did and it still took me 4 days to go!!!  (sorry if that's TMI but it seems like there is never TMI around here!!!) Good luck with everything!  You CAN do this.  Hugs!

Posts.Content: Mar 23, 2011 10:21PM mdg wrote: We all understand...none of us were ok with all of the waiting in this process!  That is the wost part of it all!  It will happen a lot, so try to get use to it!  As far as your questions, it is very much a personal choice.  I would ask your surgeon about the survival rates and the recurrance rates for both lump+rads and mastectomy.  Also ask about the risk your good side is of developing breast cancer.  These were the things that helped me make my decision for a bilateral mastectomy and immediate reconstruction with tissue expanders eventhough I am Stage I.  The other recommendation I have is to get a complete copy of your pathology report.  Study it...understand everything on it.  Also know that the picture can change once you have a mastectomy or lumpetomy when they do a final pathology report on all tissue removed.  My pathology report changed and that made me change my treatment plan.  This is a long process...it is so hard.  You can be nervous and anxious...we all were and continue to be.  You have come to a great place to learn and get support.  Best of luck!

It is never easy to get the news no matter how they do it.   I like you cried a lot!  OMG.....I kept running into the bathroom to not cry in front of my 4 year old son....I would go in the bathroom and turn on the water and the fan and just sob.  At some point you just stop crying.  I am over 2 years out now from dx and life is great. THe beginning is the hardest part.  Take it one day at a time.   You are not alone as there are many wonderful ladies here that "get it" and will walk you through each step of this.  Sending hugs!!!

I never even wanted to take aspirin before my BC diagnosis, but now I do take meds when needed to help me.  I also had a 4 year old son when I was dx.....that tugged at my heart and added a whole other stress element.  I am happy to tell you that he just turned 7 and I am doing great.  You will get there one day.  Hugs!!

Posts.Content: Feb 28, 2013 09:12AM mdg wrote: Many parts of out treatment are very much personal decisions. I was stage 1 and had BMX and chemo. I chose BMX because recurrence rates are slightly less than with lumpectomy and rads. I was also in excellent health other than BC. As far as chemo I was kind of in a gray area. One MO said no chemo for me and the other said she thought I could benefit. I also had clean nodes but did have angiolymphatic invasion. I weighed it all out and did the chemo. My son was also only 4 years old when I was diagnosed and I wanted to be aggressive with treatment. There are many reasons early stage women get chemo...age, tumor grade, family history, etc...

It was just easier this way for me.  All of the waiting to find stuff out was so hard and I just couldn't keep repeating everything to everyone while I was so emotionally wrecked.  My son is only 4 and we did not tell him anything until a few days before my surgery.  He only knew I had a "boo boo" and needed the doctor to fix it.  He asked where it was and I said in my chest.  He never really asked more questions as we just made it not sound like a big deal so we were able to keep it that simple.  Your kids however are so much older you will have to fully explain.  I am sorry you are going through this.  I know how hard it is...hugs!

Posts.Content: Mar 17, 2011 10:28PM mdg wrote: You can see my stats below.  My oncotype was 17 which is the highest in the low range.  I had angiolymphatic invasion present in my pathology from my lumpectomy meaning there was potential for a pathway for cancer to spread by blood though my lymph nodes were clear.  I did also have a BLMX in January.   I had two opinions...one said no chemo the other said there was potential for benefit from chemo and recommended it.  Both agreed that tamoxefin is a must post treatment as that will really reduce my risk.  I also had a grade 2 tumor which is a gray zone too.  Grade 1 tumors are slow growing and chemo usually attacks fast growing, rapidly dividing cells.  Grade 3 tumors are fast growing/rapidly dividing cells....grade 2 is in the middle and they just don't know. I had to make a choice ultimatly.  I opted for chemo based on grade 2, angiolymphatic invasion and the fact that I am a mom of a 4 year old.  I want to do everything I can to be here and see him grow up.  I knew I would never forgive myself if I skipped chemo and the cancer came back, but I also know there is no guarantee it won't come back.   My compromise was doing cold caps to keep my hair during chemo.  My med onc supports cold caps and has them in her office.  I hope they work...I am 15 days post my first chemo and no signs of any shedding on my head though I am losing other body hairs.  I have another week of waiting to see if it works well but the cold caps have a very good success rate with my type of chemo treatment (taxotere and cytoxan).  My treatment takes 9 weeks....4 cycles, one every 3 weeks.  I will be done by the first week of May and the summer will be mine, hopefully with my hair still in tact!

The good news is that your tumor is so small.  Definately look into oncotype.   I hope all goes well...good luck and a big hug.

Posts.Content: May 11, 2012 11:42AM mdg wrote: I requested PT because I am an active person and have been a fitness instructor for years.  I was super worried I would lose range of motion.  I had BMX and TE's placed.  I did the post surgery rehab exercises faithfully twice a day even if it hurt.  I started seeing a PT that had experience with MX patients about 3 weeks post op.  I went twice a week for about 3 months.  I did continue to do the exercises and work out daily.  I had my BMX in Jan 2011.  I started doing yoga this past fall and that has done wonders for me.  I started with yoga at my cancer center and now take a regular yoga class.  My range of motion is excellent.  My right side was worse tha my left side - don't know why but now they are the same.

Posts.Content: Oct 11, 2015 06:03PM mdg wrote: I am sorry you find yourself here...I too had a clear mammogram a few months before I found the 1 cm lump myself on a self check exam. I personally would meet with a breast surgeon and a plastic surgeon. I met with both before I made any decisions about what type of surgery to have. You will want all of your options and want to know what types of surgery the doctors recommend based on your health and situation. As far as plastic surgeons - I would also find one that does only reconstruction. Regular plastic surgeons may not have enough experience if you do decide on mx and reconstruction. Good luck! Hang in there...the beginning is the hardest part.

Posts.Content: Jun 22, 2011 10:16PM mdg wrote: I had LVI on my path report...it freaked me out too.  It means the cancer cells had a pathway to potentially travel by blood. I had clear nodes but LVI listed as "present" on pathology report.  I googled and there is not a ton of information on LVI but what I have read just indicates there was a route for the cells to have travelled - which is potentially not a great thing.  I did do chemo as I was in a gray area and needed to make the decision as it was not clear cut.  LVI did make me want to do the chemo.   Good luck...I know this is overwhelming.  I hope you get through everything OK.  Hugs!

Posts.Content: Feb 21, 2013 11:19PM mdg wrote: My MO said that having ovaries out doesn't really reduce risk of recurrence any more for those that were premenopausal before BC and on tamoxifen.  He did say that switching to an AI because of being post menopausal could provide slightly lower recurrence rates than being on tamoxifen.  I have to get my ovaries out because of cysts - not for BC but I guess it's an added bonus to have them out and switch to an AI if it helps reduce my risk a little more.
Posts.Title: Ovary Removal-Will it help? CherylinOhio mdg

Posts.Content: Jun 12, 2011 10:55AM mdg wrote: This is so sweet of you to research..your friend is lucky to have you!  Things that helped me were: 1.  Food after surgery for my family...I could care less about eating but I have a family so knowing they were taken care of and my husband would not have to cook gave me peace of mind.  My friends used a website to coordinate meals with people being able to select dates and post what they were bringing each day.  2. Cards.  I loved getting cards and personal notes in the mail.   It seems like once my surgery was over no more cards/notes.  I still had chemo and still have to deal with this emotionally for months to come. It would have been nice to have people continue to send things for laughs and encouragement.  The days I got things like this...brought me to tears with joy in knowing how much I was loved. 3.  If she is having surgery, there is a thread on the surgery board that explains items that are helpful to have on hand.  My friend brought over button down PJ's for me which was great because I could not put clothes over my head for a while right after surgery.  4.  Since she is having chemo, there is a chemo thread that also tells what things are good on hand.  As far as food for her, I liked bland things like graham crackers, wheat crackers, homemade soup (my favorite), pasta dishes, toast, bagels.  Carbs were what I wanted.....I did lose my ability to taste things after several weeks so food didn't taste good at all. They do tell you to avoid lots of raw foods during chemo in case of bacteria so keep that in mind.  I also did all organic foods and if she has a hormone related BC then anything with hormones is out unless you get it organic or homone free.  5.  Care packages:  I got a few and they were great!  These are some of the things I got: prayerblanket, small pillow, spa booties, spa hot pad thing (you put in in the microwave to warm it up), lotions (skin dries out from chemo!!!), magazines, healthy cooking magazines, books, movies, quote books, pajamas, snacks. My biggest advice is listen, don't tell cancer stories, don't say "you are strong" (I HATED that!!!), support her family (kids or spouse) and ask how they are too, check in frequently, don't complain about trivial things in your life (it's hard to listen to trivial things when you are going through BC), tell her how much she means to you..... You are a good friend....good luck to your friend.  I know how hard this is....

Posts.Content: Feb 20, 2011 05:36AM mdg wrote: Also just know that even if you think you know what it is from a biopsy, the details and final diagnosis can change after your mastectomy or lumpectomy.  I was grade 1 from the biopsy but after lumpectomy it changed to grade 2 after they evaluated the entire tumor.  After my mastectomy, they found one more area of invasive cancer.  So I guess all I am saying is that the picture can change after final surgery.  Good luck!

Posts.Content: Sep 12, 2012 09:44PM mdg wrote: They may tell you it looks like a fibroadenoma, but that can't be confirmed until you have a biopsy.  I was told to wait 6 mo's and recheck it.  I did that and it was cancer.  I would push for a biopsy either way.  Just remember the odds are in your favor...80% of lumps are benign.  Good luck!
Posts.Title: 42 with questions Mindyandgang mishka

Posts.Content: mdg wrote: I had 4 cycles of taxotere and cytoxan and got done on 5/4.  I am still dealing with an allergic reaction from the last two cycles and am so frustrated.  After my 3rd cycle about a week later I broke out in hives all over and was super itchy.  It started in a small area on my torso under my R breast and within 2 days it had spread all over my torso, down my legs and all over my arms.  I went to urgent care (it was Easter morning) and was given oral steroids.  I was on them a week and it seemed to go away but then I got my 4th treatment of chemo and 5 days later the rash was back.  My med onc's office kind of blew me off (the PA's) so I went to my IM.  She thought it was an allergic reaction and gave me more steroids for 6 days.  That seemed to help but it was not completely gone after I was done with treatment.  My IM then sent me to a dermatologist that day. The derm thought it was an allergic reaction and gave me a topical steroid so I would not have to take oral steroids again.  I keep putting it on and it helps a little but I am still super itchy everywhere.  The hives come and go but the itching happens most of the time.  No one knows what to tell me.  My med onc doesn't say much other than you are done with chemo so it will go away.  I am sooooo sick of itching.  I have scabs on my arms/legs from itching so much.  I am anemic from the chemo so I have bruises all over from itching too.  This has been going on since the middle of April!  I can't take it anymore.  I took Benedryl last night and slept better with no itching.  I can't take it during the day...it knocks me out. I am going to go get some zyrtec today and see if that helps.  Has anyone had this?  How long?  How did you get it to go away?   I have more oral steroids, should I just go back on them?  Every time I go on them the itch comes back when I get off them...it doesn't seem to work!  Any suggestions???  I am going nuts! Oh and I have not changed laundry soaps, lotions, etc.......everything has remained the same so I don't think it is from anything else. Maria Visit my BC Blog at breastcancerwontdefineme.blogs... Posts.Content: Sep 23, 2012 11:02AM mdg wrote: Hard to say....everyone is different.  Mine lasted off and on for 3 months.....I know that is not what you wanted to hear.  My docs also acted like I was crazy.  It was insulting.....like I would make that up.  The rash and scabs from itching spoke for themself!  I do know that I developed allergies to my laundry soap after chemo....really odd.  I had been using that soap which was pretty chemical free for some time before chemo and no issues...then later when I illiminated it the rash went away.  I visited my sister who uses that same laundry soap and after sleeping there (in sheets washed in it) I got the rash again immediately.  I guess what we also have to realize is that you can develop allergies to things post chemo since it messes with your immune system.  I remember how awful the rash was for me...could not sleep at all.  I would cry because it was so unbearable at times.  I had bruises all over from itching (I had over 20 bruises on one thigh!).    Steroids, topical steroids and Sarna lotion were the only things that helped me a little.  Benedryl did nothing for me but you can try it.  Good luck!

I am freaking out! If you were stage I, did you get chemo?  If so, what made the doctors decide it was important for your treatment (age, dx, oncotype dx, etc.)?  I am meeting with the medical oncologist on Monday.  I also plan to have BLMX and for now they say I won't need radiation.  They do recommend Tamoxofin though as I am pre-menopausal.  Chemo is the last thing I am freaking out about!  Just let me know your experiences.  I know I have to do what they tell me if it's the best thing, but I am trying to get my mind ready to accept it.  Ugh....I hate BC -can I just say that???? Thanks in advance ladies for putting me at ease and talking me "off the ledge".  So far you have helped a ton! Maria Visit my BC Blog at breastcancerwontdefineme.blogs... Posts.Content: Jan 7, 2011 12:14PM mdg wrote: Thanks ladies.  I know that I can get through the chemo like many of you did - not because I want to but because I have to.  I know in the end for me I can't look back and have regret my whole life that I didn't do all that I could to kick cancer forever.  I have to think that way for my 4 year old son and husband.  I just keep praying my score comes back so low that there will be no added benefit of chemo.  I just want to spare the people I love the torture of seeing me go through it and living it with me - especially my innocent little boy.  That part breaks my heart more than BLMX or anything else....knowing I have to teach him about cancer and perhaps scare him.  I know if I have to do the chemo, we will work with the counselors to figure out the right way to handle this with our son, but I just don't want to have to do it.  You know what I mean?  Please pray for a low, low score.  Test result expected in about 10-14 days.   The waiting is killing me...............
Posts.Title: If you were stage I, did you get chemo??? mdg SusansGarden

Posts.Content: Jan 8, 2011 04:11PM mdg wrote: Thanks for more responses ladies.  My medical oncologist said I would most likely get T&C X4 in three week intervals. I realize this is much more tolerable than other chemo options.  I am not afraid so much of being tired or nauseated.  I am more afraid of having it be visually obvious to my son.  I also don't like the idea of my cancer being so public (no hair = cancer, right?).  I just want to fight this battle privately and we have only told family and a few friends with specific instructions that it is not to be discussed with others.  I am usually a private person.  That is just who I am. I know if the doctors tell me there is benefit to chemo for me with my specific tumor, I have to strongly consider that as my #1 goal is to live and be here for my son.  I just wish that the surgeries would be my only treatment now so it would not potentially scare him as much.  I know it probably seems odd to some of you that are moms too that have gone through having chemo already.  For me, I just want to protect my son.  It's hard to think I will have to tell him potentially scary things or have him see things that may scare him.  I know we will have to be reassuring to him and as honest as we need to be with a 4 year old, but it will break my heart.  All I want to do is keep him happy, feeling safe and loved over everything.  It doesn't mean I can't do that with chemo, but it will be probably harder for me.  It kind of feels like you are sending your child over to a hot stove and you can't do anything to stop him from touching it and you know it will hurt him.  Maybe I sould irrational, but I am still getting use to the fact that I have cancer and am only at the beginning stage of this.  I have not gotten to a place where I believe everything will be OK again.  I guess since I lost a parent at a young age but not to cancer (I was 2 1/2), it had a profound effect on my life and still does.  I am not saying my son will lose me, but I know all the thoughts I grew up with after having something so traumatic happen to me at a young age.  I just want him to have a "normal" childhood.....more than anything.  Somehow cancer was just something that I considered "normal" I guess.  I know you can't protect your child from everything, but as a mom you want to.  I know a lot of you ladies are moms and have gone through chemo and had your kids see what that is like.  I know it was probably hard for you too.  I am sure many of you will tell me your kids are doing OK after everything.  For now, I continue to pray that my tumor will be not likely to return so I can push through the next year of BLMX and reconstruction and close the door on BC in several months.  Thank you again for all of the support and sharing your experiences.

Posts.Content: Feb 2, 2011 03:31PM mdg wrote: 1/27  I was nauseated a bit. They kept giving me things for that.  It took some time for it to stop.  At first it just felt like I couldn't get my body moving even to shift on the bed.  It took a day or two for my ab muscles to feel like I could contract them to scoot myself into positions.  I had surgery at 2pm and did eat a popcicle late night with no problem.   I did have a morphine pain pump so I could hit the button when things hurt.  That helped.  I slept for a few hours here and there.  The nurses and staff were wonderful!!! 1/28  The nausea came back.  Could not even eat a popcicle...did get sick.  One quick shot into my IV and the nausea was gone and was fine.  I was able to eat something with no problem.  I wolfed down graham crackers like they were Godiva chocolates or something!  At some point they took away my pain pump....I was yelling "it's not working!" with panic but that was when they put me on oral pain meds.   The oral meds worked well.  I ate lunch and dinner - kind of bland but it was fine and I had no trouble.  I did ask for stool softeners and started taking them today.   Since a winter storm was coming and I had a far drive they kept me over night as they were not ready to release me until late when the snow was coming down too hard.  It would have taken hours to get home. 1/29  Going home!  By 1pm I was at home in my bed.  I took pain meds an hour before leaving so I would not feel much.  The ride was over and hour and I slept like a baby with my blanket from home and 3 pillows.  I climbed the stairs and got in bed.  I was very tired.  Not much pain.  I was able to lift my arms up higher than I thought! 1/30 Drains are draining less!  Yea!  I am almost below the 30cc's per day on both sides.  I took a bath (waist down) and my friend helped me wash my hair.  I even blow dried it myself!  I was shocked!  I was able to eat a nice lunch and dinner.  Still taking stool softeners.....and a laxitive.  No moevement (if you know what I mean!) 1/31  Feeling good.  Took a bath and got dressed by myself slowly - but I did it!  Still taking pain meds every few hours but I feel hardly any pain when I take them.  About 5 hours after taking them the pain creeps in a little so I take more.  Still eating ok but mid day the pain meds make me a bit queezy/drowsy.  I eat wheat crackers with every pain pill to protect my stomach.  Still taking stool softeners and more laxitives.  No luck yet! 2/1  Last night my stomach was a mess..woke up constipated horribly in the middle of the night!  My poor DH went to the pharmacy twice in the middle of the night!  Supposetories and yes, the dreaded enema.  I was so desperate but felt better after it was all done.  Now a bit of diarrhea from the laxitives.  This was the WORST part of my recovery so far - honestly!  So keep on the stool softeners, water and if needed laxitives as a precaution!!!! Today I got up and took a bath alone!  Got dressed alone.   Brought my lunch up to my bedroom by myself (I feel like this is something my 4 year old would say and be proud of!).  I have not taken any pain meds since 5am this morning...getting my drains out tomorrow!  I could have had them out today but we have a blizzard....darn snow!  These are the things I used the most in the past few days: lip balm, hand lotion, tons of pillows, wedge pillow, pillows under my knees, blanket to throw over shoulders, camisole provided by hospital with pockets to hold drains (this was the best!), tank tops with shelf bra, soft open front hoodie like sweat shirts, heating pad (well, something you put in the microwave and heat up and put on neck/legs or sore body parts - or under the covers to warm you when you are cold), laxitives, stool softeners, sleeping pills (ambien), water, lots of healthy food (veggies/fiber, protein), wheat crackers, nice comfy jammies.  As far as medical supplies - shoe laces for keeping drains out of the way when you bathe, drain gauze pad dressings, peroxide, q tips, paper medical tape, alcohol wipes to strip drains and antibiotic cream to clean drain sites.  I guess I felt compelled to come over here and try my best to ease your mind just a little.  I know how it feels.....please know you will be OK.  You can get through this.......HUGS to all of you.  If you have questions PM me.  I don't mind at all.......Best of luck to all of you wonderful gals!!!!  I am sending healthy vibes, quick recovery thoughts and prayers!!!!!  :)

GOOD LUCK FEB GALS!   I am cheering you on!!!

Posts.Content: May 29, 2014 05:09AM mdg wrote: I am so sorry about your diagnosis.....sending hugs!  The beginning is the hardest part.  Once you know your treatment and surgery plan it gets a little easier somehow.  Get a copy of your pathology report and understand it.....write down your questions for your surgeon before you go.  I also had no real family history and was a fitness professional with a clear mammogram...I found the lump a few months later and the mammogram never caught it.  Don't feel stupid....many of us got here just like you.  I was also fooled by the BRCA gene info.  I wish the "awareness" info would tell women:  only a LOW percentage of woman actually have BRCA that get BC and that mammograms are not thorough!!!  Hang in there!  :)
Posts.Title: Am I a hot mess? loris66 vbishop

Posts.Content: Feb 9, 2011 07:52AM mdg wrote: Hi Gals,  I am just popping back over from the Jan 2011 MX board to offer some support.  I am 13 days post BLMX and doing great!  I am doing my physical therapy exercises and doing everything except lifting things over 5 lbs (I had BLMX with TE placement).  I am going to start driving as I have been off the pain meds for a week!  I can tell you getting off the pain meds had made  my head and emotional state much better.  Those just messed with me.......I am sleeping flat for part of the night which is nice.  I have not used my wedge pillow at all in days.  For now I am still taking a sleep aid at night.  I don't sleep great, but it is gradually getting better each night which is good.  I do sleep, but I wake a few times a night but at least now I can fall back to sleep.  I can sleep on my side for a while too which is nice to give my backside a rest.  I have good range of motion in my arms and can do most things I need to for myself - just no heavy lifting.  I just wanted to reassure you that you can get through this!  I did way better than I thought.  Good luck!  If you have questions, PM me.  I don't mind.  Take a deep breath.  I know how hard this is.  It gets better after surgery.  I really feel good :)

It was no longer a fibroadenoma. I hope you are luckier than I was. I am sure they will wAnt to do a biopsy to identify what it is. Good luck!
Posts.Title: Fibroadenoma that has changed in a 'concerning way'? HeatherGF HeatherGF

Posts.Content: Sep 24, 2013 06:26PM mdg wrote: I am so sorry  you find yourself one of us.....breaks my heart every time someone else gets "the news!".  I never in a million years thought I would be here....but like everyone else...I am!  My son was only 4 when I was diagnosed.  I am happy to tell you I was diagnosed almost three years ago and I am doing very well.  I have gotten through my treatments and remain on oral medication for a few more years.  Another survivor told me something right after I was diagnosed.  She held my hand and looked at me and said "there IS life after breast cancer".  Just remember that.  It will probably be a crappy 10-12 months, but after that life slowly returns to normal.  You are forver changed after year hear the words "you have breast cancer", but it does not define you and your life.  Take it one day at a time and one step at a time!
Posts.Title: In Total Shock!!!!!!! carissabforlife Kiko

Posts.Content: Mar 9, 2013 10:20AM mdg wrote: First of all, so sorry you have also gotten diagnosed.  It is a very overwhelming thing to hear from the doctor and process in our minds.  The beginning for me was just like you....I spent all day on the phone, computer and scheduling appointments with various people at the hospital.  It was like a full time job!  I found it very overwhelming and it was hard to digest everything that was happening.  Just remember one thing...you don't have to do what they say when they say.  You have a choice to schedule things as you want to.  For example, I don't think I would make any decisions about everything until I knew the oncotype score and the BRCA status.  That can tell a lot.  With BRCA they usually recommend BMX and oophrectomy I think (not my area of expertise!).  If you have to have all of these surgeries, I am sure you would like to know that up front.  As far as reconstruction, I met with two plastic surgeons before I even decided to have a BMX.  I knew that what type of reconstruction I would have would also be part of my decision making process.  I wanted DIEP but I was not a candidate for that.  The only thing either surgeon would do for me is tissue expanders and implants because I was too thin for DIEP and I am a big exercise person so they would not do any procedures involving muscle as it would effect my ability to do activities I enjoyed.  I was not expecting that to be the case.  I did move forward with the implants and am very happy with my results, but I had not planned to go that route initially.  Just make sure you have all the information you need before you do anything.  Once you get moving, somehow this process gets a little easier.  I am so sorry that you have to go through this too...just know there IS life after breast cancer.  I was 45 two years ago when I was diagnosed.  Now life is normal again and better than before BC.  Hugs!
Posts.Title: Treatment plan moving fast Chrisesta67 gemini4

Posts.Content: May 12, 2011 09:27PM mdg wrote: Hi Sue!  Welcome to the boards.  I started my journey in December and just finished my final TC treatment last week!  I had four treatments like you will.  All I can tell you is hang with the gals on the May 2011 chemo board...I am on the March Chemo Lounge board and the gals have been awesome!  I do want to tell you that not EVERYONE has a hard time with chemo. I did exceptionally well - better than anyone expected.  The things that helped me were: I chose not to buy in to feeling like crap because of chemo.  Yes, sometimes you do feel like crap, but I started every day saying I feel good and tried to live that.  I worked out daily - even on the day I had bad bone pain.  I kept moving.  That made all the difference for me.  I exercised 5 days a week through all of chemo...didn't miss any workouts except infusion day. I also planned for side effects...iced fingers/toes, took prilosec for heartburn, took claritin/aleve for bone pain, took stool softeners/senakot for constipation, etc.....Once I had my experience from the first round (body aches, bone pain, constipation) I knew how to plan for the other treatments.  The other treatments were much better. I also planned ahead at home...I made food and froze it before chemo so I had stuff to eat that sounded good.  I loved home made soup.  I also ate tons of pasta - carbs was all I wanted. I tried to do normal things...I got up and got my son off to school every morning..didn't miss one.  I feel like if I laid around, I would buy into feeling crappy so I just tried to do normal things.  On the weekends after chemo I just didn't plan much in case I felt crappy but the rest of the time we did everything we normally do.  It's only 9 weeks...then you will be done. It went really fast for me.  I still can't believe I am done.  I hope this encourages you...I was petrified before chemo....I get it!  I didn't think I could do it..now I can't believe I did it.  You will say the same thing in 8 1/2 more weeks girl!  Feel free to PM me if I can help support you.  I would love to do that...so many others did that for me through all of this. Best of luck!
Posts.Title: Just started TC 2 days ago and looking for support Sue53 alexanjb

Posts.Content: Apr 28, 2012 05:10PM mdg wrote: I was 45 when dx and my son was 4 years old.  I had an oncotype of 17 but had angiolymphatic invasion and clear nodes.  I did BMX and then the chemo was a toss up because of grade 2 and angiolymphatic invasion.  I got two opinions on chemo - one med onc said no to chemo the other said I could benefit. I don't think they really know...this is all a mystery and everyone's body is different.  I opted for chemo and did TCx4.  I used cold caps to keep my hair.  Chemo was over in 9 weeks and it was not as bad as I imagined it would be.  I wanted to look back with NO regret and take every treatment available to me for my young son.  I am on tamoxifen now too.
Posts.Title: In your 40's with low Oncotype score, what was your decision? gracebead p22nut5

Posts.Content: Mar 12, 2011 05:48AM mdg wrote: We used all of the tools to make decisions.  For me the adjuvent offered more of a benefit from the chemo than the oncotype test did.  I was forced to decide on chemo as I was in a gray area.  For me the thing that tipped me to take chemo was the fact that I had "angiolymphatic invasion" listed as present on the pathology report.  That scared me enough to take chemo...but I didn't want to lose my hair....so I decided on chemo and the cold caps so I could keep my hair.  I had chemo #1 last week.  I am just going to get through this....and get it over with.  8 more weeks - not that I am counting or anything.  I would ask for oncotype but realize that in many cases you may still have to make the call on chemo unless your score comes back really, really low.

Posts.Title: Diagnosed in Dec Mina49 one-L

Posts.Content: Feb 9, 2013 08:54AM mdg wrote: I went on STD because my job was too stressful and kind of physical (I was in sales and had to drive a lot, stand for hours and lift a heavy sales bag in/out of my car multiple times a day).  I was off work from late Jan to mid May.  I had a BMX and chemo for 9 weeks.  I stayed off during chemo because I was a surgical/hospital sales rep and my MO didn't think it would be a good idea for me to hang out in hospitals all day while going through chemo.  I went back to work a few weeks after chemo but then had to go out again the next month for exchange surgery.  I was off for 2 months because of pain from the surgery in my ribs which made it impossible for me to lift anything and stand for hours.  I finally went back to work again but then my husband got a job out of state and we had to move.  Since then I did not return to work.  I am starting a business and being a full time mom.  I don't think emotionally I could handle working through chemo.  The emotional strain was hard on me and I had a hard time focusing on things.  This is the only time in my life I did not work and I felt like I needed to take care of myself and put myself first (which is something I usually don't do).  I was lucky to be in a situation with good STD and a spouse that works so financially it was fine.  I know many people are not as fortunate.  I guess I would just evaluate your financial situation and see how you feel.  Some people work through chemo and do fine.  I felt OK during chemo - was able to exercise daily and never had nausea so if I was mentally in a good place I could have worked.  Good luck with all of this.  I know how hard it is.  Hugs!
Posts.Title: Working Fulltime bhlri rozem

Posts.Content: Oct 22, 2011 01:01PM mdg wrote: This is such a personal decision and it's a hard one!  I can only tell you what things helped me decide what the right thing was for me.  I was 45 when diagnosed and my son is only 4.   You can see my stats below and my oncotype score was 17.  The things that made me determine lump vs MX were: age of my son - I wanted to be as aggressive as I could pathology report indicated I had angiolymphatic invasion survival rates between lump+rad vs. MX were the same but recurrence rates were NOT the same I had a higher chance of getting BC in my other breast now that I had it in one breast I knew I would want reconstruction and I always wanted larger breasts (I was an A+ before surgery) I opted for BMX and I had TE's placed and got my implant exchange in June.  There are various reconstruction options - so meet with a PS before you make a decision to discuss all of this and just know your options even if you choose lumpectomy.  I also found after meeting with two PS's that I was not a candidate for many procedures - I was only offered reconstruction with TE's and implants as I did not have enough body fat for DIEP and because I am so active (I teach aerobics) my surgeons would not remove any muscle from my body for reconstruction as it would diminish my ability to do what I love.  I would still meet with a PS even if you are not sure just to know all of your options.
Posts.Title: Lumpectomy vs. Masectomy three17 annettek

Posts.Content: Jul 31, 2011 04:45PM mdg wrote: I am sorry about your diagnosis...we are similar in diagnosis except for mine was IDC.  I too tell everyone I am fine and act normal but I can only tell the truth here among the other women that understand my fears and emotions.  This has been a hard journey but in time it gets better..either that or you just fight the emotions and move forward (I am not sure which one is right.....).  None of us feel brave...we just do what we have to.  As someone once posted here "if a 500 lb beast was chasing you, you would run fast too".  It's not like anyone deals with the beast chasing them easily......and BC is just that, a beast.  Just know here you are in great company.  The women here have helped me so much since I started this in December.  Hugs and good luck to you...I am sorry that you had to join us.

Posts.Content: Jan 6, 2012 03:31PM mdg wrote: I exercised 5 days a week through chemo at a gym.  I did have neulasta shots but I never got sick at all.  I did wipe down equipment with the wipes my gym provides.  I did an hour on the elliptical each day and some weights a few times a week.  I am also a fitness instructor but my Med Onc would not let me teach classes during chemo.....grrr!  I did get back to teaching a few weeks post chemo though.  I just listened to my body.  Some days I was able to do more exercise....some days less.  I just did what I could and was sure to do a lot of stretching and relaxation stuff at the end of my workouts.  You may check and see if there is a cancer center that offers exercise classes....that may be an option.  I do yoga once a week at my local cancer center.

Posts.Title: TRYING to be positive BIRADS 5 sassyon3rd sassyon3rd

Posts.Content: Jun 5, 2011 03:28PM mdg wrote: Hey Deb, I did not know all of this was going on with your oncotype!  I got back to work last week and have been on the boards less.  What a horrible decision....and a mess too!  HUgs!  As we talked before, my first onc said no chemo if 17 or below but at 18 or higher (in the intermedicate range) the decision would be mine.  As you know, my score was 17 but I too had lymphavascular invasion present.  I did have a BLMX and was node clear with a tumor less than 2cm.  I did do the chemo for a few reasons Second opinion med onc said at tumor board 3 of 4 med onc's agreed chemo would benefit me despite an oncotype score of 17 and a grade 2 tumor.   They did consider age (46), overall health (I am in excellent shape/health other than BC), lymphavascular invasion and grade 2.  My recurrence rate based on oncotype and using tamoxifen was 11% but they felt I would benefit further from having the chemo and could tolerate TC x 4 pretty well.  It was no "picnic" but it was not that bad for me.  As you already know, I used cold caps and kept my hair.  I really agonized over this decision more than anything I had to go through since DX.  Ultimately my decision came from considering having a young child (age 4), lymphavascular invasion present and being in good health.  I also knew that if the BC came back I would never be able to live with myself or face my son if I had NOT done the chemo.  At this point I know I have done EVERYTHING I could have done to help myself live.  I had an aggressive BLMX, chemo and have changed my diet to the Anti Cancer book's recommendations.  I also have committed to continue exercising 5 days a week to further reduce risk and take tamoxifen (I started that this week).  I hope that I tolerate tamoxifen well - and if for some reason I don't I know at least I did chemo.  I can live with my decision without regret.  That is why I chose this treatment path.  This was what was best for ME and each person has to decide what is right for them personally.  There is NO one right answer...only the right answer for you. Good luck with your decision.  If I can help...PM me.  Hugs!!!

Posts.Content: Jul 11, 2011 07:03PM mdg wrote: It does sound like Grade 3 which is more aggressive than Grade 1 and 2.  As far as vascular invasion- that means there are cancer cells in vascular areas which means there is a potential pathway for the cells to have travelled by blood.  I had angiolymphatic invasion on my pathology report too.  It sounds like yours is not confirmed yet - after the surgery they will know.  Most people don't have surgery right away after dx..it seems like most people have to wait a month or two until all the tests are done, they have seen the surgeons and then get it scheduled.  I was DX on 12/13 and did not have BLMX until Jan 27.  I am sorry about your diagnosis...glad you found these boards for support and information. Hugs!

Posts.Content: Mar 7, 2013 10:35PM mdg wrote: I got two opinions immediately from two different NCI's.  I met with a breast surgeon and plastic surgeon from each hospital.  I decided to meet with the plastic surgeons too so that I could have accurate reconstruction information before I made a decision on lumpectomy+radiation or a bilateral mastectomy.  I felt that knowing that was important to making my decision.  I was a candidate for lumpectomy or MX and was also stage 1.   I am glad I got a second opinion.   The second hospital wanted to all of their own tests and they compared them to the other hospital's tests. The second opinion changed my pathology from grade 1 to grade 2 and also found some additional calcifications in my breast that were not seen by the first opinion.  I am glad I got the second opinion and glad I had the BMX.  My final pathology showed another tiny invasive area that we did not know about.   I was fortunate my insurance covered second opinions.  Sorry that your wife has to go through this....hugs!
Posts.Title: When should we get a second opinion? JohnLeo InspiredbyDolce

Posts.Content: Feb 11, 2011 07:50AM mdg wrote: You never know.  You see my stats below and I had an oncotype test done and the score was 17.  I had two opinions on chemo.  The first opinion said no chemo.  The second opinion said chemo would be a benefit.  I am also 45 and premenopausal and decided on chemo.  It isn't going to be fun but I want to be here for my young son who is only 4.  If this gives me a better chance, I will do it!  What I found out after the final pathology was:  my Grade 1 tumor was upgraded to Grade 2; oncotype score; angiolymphatic invasion in the tumor; after BLMX they found one more small area of cancer at 2mm that was not detected before the BLMX.  The bottom line is that the pathology could change after the lumpectomy.  Are they doing the oncotype test?  You may ask.  If your score on that is really low then chemo may be able to be avoided.  My score was technically in the low range at 17, but the intermediate range starts at score 18 so that did not make me feel so secure.  I hope you don't need chemo, but remember if you do, it will blast anything floating in your body that surgery won't get.  I know the waiting and antcicipation is hard......especially where chemo is concerned.  I agonized over this...cried daily.  Now that I know I am going chemo, I am OK.  My compromise is doing cold caps to keep my hair.  If that works like they tell me, I go through chemo looking just like myself and be done with all of this right after chemo and move on with my hair in tact!  Good luck.  THe lumpectomy was not that bad in my opinion.  I was back to the gym the next week and back to teaching aerobics 10 days later.  :)

Organix shampoo/conditioner (Walmart, Target, Meijer has it) Renpure Hairspray (it is organic) Deodorent - Nature's Path Lotion - Burt's Bees and Alba Toothpaste- Tom's Still working on some of the cleaning products.  I have been buying 7th Generation at Target but I need to read up on more of that and see if I need to make more changes.  Hope this helps.  It takes a lot of time to research all of this crap!!!  Good luck!

Posts.Content: Apr 6, 2011 10:24PM mdg wrote: I can understand how scared you are and yes, you are so young.  I want to tell you that I consider myself young (45 - which I am sure sounds old to you!) but I too am active.  I teach aerobics and have a 4 year old son.  I am a bikini wearing mama and love to be really physically active.  Getting BC was a complete shock..I have no family history at all.  I had a BLMX on Jan 27th and am in the middle of chemo.  I am ready to teach aerobics, but my medical oncologist won't let me until after chemo (boo!) though I continue to workout 5 days a week.  Anyway...I had reconstruction done with tissue expanders and I will get my implants in June.  I feel great really.  The tissue expanders are ugly (so time your surgery in the winter months where they are covered up!) but look ok in most clothes for now.  I have worked with a physical therapist to make sure I did not lose any range of motion through this.  I can tell you I have NO pain or tightness even with the tissue expanders at this point.  I guess I just want to give you hope that all will be OK.  I am the kind of person that doesn't even like to take motrin for a headache so going through this was scary for me!  I can tell you the BLMX was not as bad as I thought at all.  It kind of felt like a bad workout feeling.  I was off pain meds on 5 days.  I got drains out within a week and that was delayed because of a snowstorm...I could have had them out in 5 days.  I did the fills...I have one more to go.  My best advice is to stretch (whatever stretches your plastic surgeon gives you) because it gets tight, but like I said, I did PT exercises and stretches daily since surgery and have ZERO tightness anymore.  You can do this.  I am blogging my journey....if you want to hear how it was after surgery, it's on there.  Good luck!

There are still other chemos though.  Good luck!

Posts.Content: Feb 15, 2011 08:11PM mdg wrote: I had a BLMX on 1/27.  I did have constipation for a few days so wiping wasn't an issue!  I had TE placed too.  I could move my arms - not too much at first, but enough to eat, go to the bathroom, brush teeth, etc.... I could lift them up over my head within the first day or two post op - but not straight up extended - they were kind of bent and out to the side a bit. At this point I have most of my range of motion back - just a little short on a few things.  You wil not need anyone to wipe your butt.....consider yourself lucky if you actually poop the first few days.  Take my advice....take stool softeners right away (in the hospital) and have some laxitives or fiber things on hand in case.  The worst part of my BLMX was the constipation..honestly!  Oh - my drains did not hurt much.  THey could have come out by day 5 post op but we had a bad snow storm so I had to wait a day or two since the hospital was an hour drive.  I didn't have any issue with the drains - they didn't hurt much to me at all.  It did feel better once they were out, but they didn't really bother me much when they were in.  Good luck!  I know how scary this is...believe me.  It was WAY easier than I thought - honestly.

Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed and trying to keep it together... SoccerMom20

Posts.Content: Jan 20, 2013 08:13AM mdg wrote: I had TCx4 and had constipation so bad the first time.  I started taking docalax and senokot the morning of chemo and continued taking it for 4-5 days following chemo for the next 3 treatments and it was much better.  I also ate lots of fiber and it did not help at all that first time......good luck!
Posts.Title: Constipation following Chemo honeybair helenlouise

Posts.Content: Jun 12, 2011 01:07PM mdg wrote: I did TC x 4 and finished on 5/4.  It was not that bad.  My biggest issues were constipation in the days following chemo, heart burn day of chemo and for a day or two after, loss of taste, tiredness, a few aches here and there, dry skin and I did develop a itching rash that finally just went away (I think!!!).  I did lose my taste for most of chemo after about the 3rd or 4th week into treatment.  It came back about 2 weeks post chemo (yea!).  I tried to combat side effects by planning in advance: I took stool softeners and laxitives starting the day of chemo for about 5 days I took claritin on the day of neulasta shot along with aleve and had no bone pain after my first treatment.  The aches were minimal too.  I continued taking aleve and claritin for about 4 days after chemo just in case. I had benedryl in my premeds to help avoid allergy to the chemo....still got a rash after chemo 3 and 4. I took prilosec the day of chemo and for 2 days after just in case. I also drank lots of water the day of chemo and the following days - probably at least 15 large glasses of water per day. I also got super hungry from steroids....ate tons of carbs!!! It was the only thing I wanted other than home made organic veggie soup.  I did not have any nausea and never took the nausea meds at all..I was really lucky.  I did also ice my fingers and toes during taxotere to avoid neuropathy in fingers and toes.  That worked fine for me - I had no issues with that.
Posts.Title: Husband started Taxotere/Cytoxen June 2011 Haljen Haljen

I exercised daily through chemo and think that it really helped. I drank tons of water too. It was easier than I thought it would be. Good luck....I hope you feel just as good.
Posts.Title: Differences in Side Effects PamCA claireinaz

Posts.Content: Jan 19, 2013 07:00AM mdg wrote: Just wanted to send hugs.  So sorry you joined our little club :(   As far as your friend, you will have to have a chat with her and tell her how much you love her and appreciate her willingness to help you but what you really need right now is someone to listen and support the decisions you make regarding treatment and you have decided to go the regular medical route.  You could also tell her that you are dealing with so much emotion right now it would be easier if she didn't discuss treatment ideas with you.  If she can't handle that conversation then it would be really selfish of her.....  I know it will be hard to talk to her, but this is about YOU, not her.  Sometimes you have to remind people of that.  As far as the chemo and hair, yes there is the cold cap option to keep your hair.  I did it and it worked well for me.  At least there is something to look into as a solution.  I know all of this is so overwhelming - we all "get it" since we have lived it too.  Take it one step at a time and you WILL push through this and be OK on the other side.  Hugs!

Posts.Title: If you were stage I, did you get chemo??? mdg SusansGarden

Posts.Content: Jan 4, 2011 08:53PM mdg wrote: Thanks for all of the good responses to my original post.  I met with the medical oncologist yesterday and ordered the oncotype dx test.  Right now I am in a waiting pattern.  They did also tell me the upgraded my Grade 1 to a Grade 2 based on the final pathology report from the lumpectomy.  THey said a majority of the tumor had Grade 1 cells but there were a few small areas that showed some Grade 2 cells.  My tumor was 1.4cm.  For now my medical onc said she will only push for chemo if my score is high.  If it's in the gray zone, then it's a personal choice as she just can't tell me that it will benefit me or not.  If it's low she says there won't be benefit for me.  She said if I needed chemo it would most likely be 4x T & C.  I am not so much worried about the tiredness or nausea, I am most freaked out by the hair thing.  I have a 4 year old son and I just don't want to have to explain "cancer" to him at this point.  If all I need is surgery and no chemo, that allows me to explain this to him when he is older especially if there is no other obvious things going on and they are giving me a great prognosis with low chance of recurrence.  I just keep thinking about my neice and nephew too that just lost their dad last year to cancer.  I am more of a mess over the potential of chemo than the BLMX because of the kids.......ugh.  The two weeks of waiting is going to be long.  I will post an update when I know the outcome.  Thanks ladies!
Posts.Title: If you were stage I, did you get chemo??? mdg SusansGarden

Posts.Content: Jan 12, 2011 08:07AM mdg wrote: Mom2Kids - I have chosen BLMX and immediate reconstruction.  Already being aggressive with surgical option.  To all, I am sure my son will be OK no matter what - I am just having a harder time worrying about him.  So overwhelmed and surgery was just scheduled for 1/27.  I have not told him about the surgery yet.  Plan to tell him a week or so before the surgery.  I also plan to buy him some special little treats/gifts for the few days I am at the hospital with a special note/card - he will love that.  I have travelled for business so he knows sometimes I am not here for that so he should be ok for the actual surgery dates.  I am planning his first sleep over with his best friend for my surgery date.  He will have some fun things to look forward to at that time which will make me feel better if he is happy/excited.    There is so much to deal with - I hate breast cancer really.  I know I have to take this one step at a time and I can get through the surgery first before chemo would start if needed.  I guess I have to explain it to him one step at a time too.  Taking lots of deep breaths and starting some relaxation exercises to calm myself..............

Posts.Title: If you were stage I, did you get chemo??? mdg SusansGarden

Posts.Content: Jan 21, 2011 01:10PM mdg wrote: Thanks ladies for all the support.  I met with another med onc today for a second opinion and it was very interesting.  SHe at first said no chemo recommended but then when she reviewed my questions and concerns and really listened, she was not sure if she would recommend no chemo.  SHe is reviewing my case at tumor board and doing some research on new studies relative to additional risk reductions from ovarian oblation.  She also reviewed my case on adjuvent online at that indicated a 5% risk reduction over tamoxafen alone.  She said the driving factor on the 5% was my age and the fact that I have a Grade 2 tumor.  She wants to review the individual components of the oncotype score test results and evaluate what really drove the score to 17.   I am meeting with her again in 2 weeks.  I really liked her interest and the fact that she wants to review some newer studies since I am in a little bit of a gray area.  I don't have answers yet, but I glad I am getting a second opinion.  Will keep you posted.

Posts.Title: In shock for a different reason - PREGNANT! Letlet kathleen1966

Posts.Content: Apr 26, 2011 09:08PM mdg wrote: I am sorry you have to go through this too....big HUG to you!  I started my journey in December and am a mom of a 4 year old.  This has been quite a journey, but I am getting through it.  I think the further you get into things it somehow gets easier.  I can't actually believe I am saying that, but it feels that way.  I guess in time you accept the "new normal" somehow and push on through each step.   As far as how to prepare....there are so many helpful posts on here for anything you can need to know.  As far as planning, read the post about surgery supplies.  That helped me get everything I needed together before surgery.  I also planned something really fun for my son when I had surgery.  He had a sleep over at his cousin's house and he was so excited he was less worried about me.  I also was fortunate to have friends provide meals for my family for about 2 weeks.  I cooked and froze things we liked before so I had extra stuff on hand.  I also shopped and stocked up before surgery.  I did have a few play dates scheduled the first weekend I was home in case I was tired and my son was bored.  He enjoyed seeing his friends and it gave my husband and I some time together.  You will need someone to care for you after a BLMX for at least a week so think about that.  My husband was able to telecommute for part of that time which helped.  I only really needed help with lifting things or getting meals during the day so he was able to work most of the day with no interuption from me.  You won't be able to drive for a few weeks....my PS said not for 3 weeks so arrange rides for your kids to school/activities.  If you have more questions about my BLMX you can PM me.  I am happy to help.  I have also been blogging my journey.  Link is below. Best of luck to you....
Posts.Title: I'm 39 with breast cancer, need advice mommyrnx2 waltersmith

Posts.Content: Apr 26, 2011 10:54PM mdg wrote: Oh and as far as the kid's sleep over...I told my son about the sleep over way before I told him I was having my boo boo fixed at the hospital.  It seemed to overshadow what was going on with me which is just how I wanted it to go.  We just kept talking about how much fun he was going to have for about 5 days and then we told him I was getting a boo boo fixed at the hospital.  I also told him that when he got home I was going to be resting and couldn't run and play but I could still read books, play wii with him and draw picturess and play board games.  I also told him I was going to get him some special treats while I was at the hospital (well, I did not buy them there...but you know....).  I did have a few things we could do together for him when he returned home as promised (new coloring book, new wii game that did not require me to move my arms, new board game and new book).  He was so excited when he got home and I was there and he got a goodie bag!  He really was not upset that I had a surgery but he does not understand the "big C" and we never used that word since he's only 4.  He did send me off to the hospital with one of his stuffed animals and insisted I sleep with it at home for a few weeks too until I was feeling better....kids are so adorable! I can tell you one other thing I learned...kids really pick up things from how you act.  The first day my hubby left me home alone I got showered and put make up  on as a friend was taking me to lunch.  When my son got home from school he said "mommy I am so proud of you...I love you!".  I asked why he was proud of me and he said "because you are all better".  I never went without make up and getting out of jammies again.  I didn't want him to think I was sick.....just something I learned.  Darn those kids...teaching us things hu?
Posts.Title: I'm 39 with breast cancer, need advice mommyrnx2 waltersmith

Posts.Content: Dec 20, 2012 01:09PM mdg wrote: Chemo is suppose to kill and stray cells of cancer in the body.  The pill will help prevent hormones from fueling any stray cells (there is more than one pill and they work a little differently - one is for pre-menopausal women and the other is for post menopausal women).  The oncotype dx test is used a lot and can be helpful although I don't know who specifically it is recommended for.  I think it use to be more for node negative women, but now I believe they use it in some women that are node positive.   I had the test done and I was node negative.  I hope this helps with some of your questions a little.

Posts.Content: Jan 14, 2011 04:10PM mdg wrote: Got my score back.........17.  Ok technically it is in the low range, but why did it have to be the highest number in the low range?  It makes me uneasy that at 17 they don't recommend chemo but at 18 it's a personal choice because they just can't be sure there is benefit or not.  Now what?  I am waiting for the medical oncologist to call me back to answer my questions.  I don't even know at this point what my % rist of recurrence is exactly for that score.  I was hoping it would just come back very low so it wouldn't matter.  Now I will probably seek a second opinion from the other national cancer institute just to see what both medical onc's say.  Isn't any of this going to be easy?  Geez.......I would pour a glass of wine, but it sounds like that will make my cancer come back too!  What's a girl suppose to do?

Posts.Content: Dec 31, 2010 02:28PM mdg wrote: Loving MOther - I would do as the other gals recommended.  Get the pathology report and have everything explained to you.  I would push for having as many tests done as they can to arm you with information to make the right decision.  I have learned so much on this board and have gone through what I call "BC for Dummies" in the past 3 weeks since getting dx.  This time spent on here has been invaluable.  I had a SNB on 12/23 and while in the surgery my surgeon decided to just remove the tumor too - which was not part of the plan since I want BLMX anyway.  He said it was right there and he saw it so he just took it out and sent it off to pathology.  I am glad he did this - now we know more information, which probably won't change my decision for BLMX, but I feel more at peace knowing as much as I can.  The SNB also indicated that my 2 nodes removed were clear.  Right now based on all that has been done, my treatment looks like BLMX (my choice over lumpectomy), no radiation, Tamoxafin and chemo is unknown yet.  The only thing I am waiting on is the oncotype dx test.  I meet with the medical oncologist Monday for the first time to order the test and discuss the chemo thing.  My surgeon said they may just do chemo because of my age or they may just rely on the oncotype dx test to determine my benefit.  I keep hoping I will get no chemo, but I have no control and will just wait and see.  As far as the lumpectomy and SNB.  It was not that bad.  I took the pain meds for the first day or two and even baked my xmas chocolate chip pound cake the evening of my surgery.  I am 8 days out and have some discomfort, but I stopped taking pain meds after 2 days.  I am recovering nicely.  I am a small B - in fact more like an A+.  I don't see any difference in my breast size.  My tumor was 1.4 cm.  I know if I were going to have lumpectomy I would need to have additional surgery because margins were close so I don't know how it would look after that.  I hope that helps explain a little.  I was assumming half of my breast would be gone because I am so small. YOu can't even tell other than the incision.  The incision is small and closed nicely.  I am sure it won't be noticeable, but then again I won't have my breasts anyway.  Like everyone else said, the decision is yours to make.  I have elected to go more aggressive despite the fact that I am stage I with a less aggressive, low grade, hormone receptor positive cancer.  I am a worry person with a young child. I hope this will be my one and only dealing with BC and after my surgery I can close the BC door forever.  I know I would worry too much about lumpectomy.  That's just who I am.  I am very at peace with my decision and know I am doing the right thing for ME.  Please continue to ask questions and post your concerns.  The experienced gals here will help and support you. Educate yourself on these tests and what the results mean so you can factor that into your decision making.  You are doing great.....you will make the right decision for YOU and feel OK with that.  I wish you good luck and health in 2011!
Posts.Title: Just Diagnosed :( loving_mother nwest125

Posts.Content: Jul 9, 2011 03:34PM mdg wrote: I am sorry you are going through this...especially for a second time.  I did have BLMX but I did do immediate reconstruction with TE's and I just got my implants 2 weeks ago.  I was so worried my DH would not think I was attractive anymore....I was so wrong.  He was obsessed with my TE's as gross as I thought they were....his attention towards me has not changed.  Unfortunately due to chemo and tamoxifen I have lost my "mojo" and am still trying to find it!  I know you are not able to do reconstruction right away so it's not the same, but my DH was still acting the same way when my TE's were not even filled up.  This is so much to process.  In time you do get use to the new you and the new normal.  It takes time.... I hate to sound so cliche....but it's true.  The drains for me were ready to come out in 5 days....some people don't have them long.  The pain from the BLMX was not as bad as I thought it would be....I was only on pain meds about 5 days.  I was back to walking 2 1/2 weeks post OP and back to the elliptical without using my arms 4 weeks post OP.    Quite honestly I found chemo more of a pain than the BLMX.  Best of luck...Hugs!
Posts.Title: Emotionally and physically scared of bmx bak94 del4

Posts.Content: Nov 7, 2011 10:11PM mdg wrote: I am sorry you have to go through this.  I did the chemo - I did TC x 4 and tolerated it pretty well.  I worked out 5 days a week through all of chemo and only missed infusion days.  I had some side effects, but not too bad.  I never needed a pill for nausea either.  I also used cold caps to keep my hair during chemo.  I finished chemo in May and have most of my hair - it's down to the middle of my back.  I just turned 46 and have a 5 year old son and he never saw me looking sick.  I feel great now!  I know it's terrifying...chemo scared me more than the BMX.  Take a deep breath.....many people to OK on the newer chemos.  Feel free to PM if I can help support you at all.  Hugs!

Posts.Title: Core Needle Biopsy experience christiansmom anitaph

Posts.Content: Jun 1, 2011 08:11PM mdg wrote: Ask your surgeons about recurrence rates.  The survival rates are the same but the recurrence rates are different.  I do not have ILC, I have IDC and was stage one and selected BLMX with reconstruction because I am 45 with a young child and I don't want to ever deal with this again.  I know there is no guarantee but it gives me better odds.  I am also taking tamoxifen because that reduces my risk significantly.  It is a personal choice.  For me it was not only about survival, but quality of life.  Having recurrences would diminish my quality of life as I know what having this once occurance has already done to my life.  I don't want to deal with this again so I will do everything I can to increase my odds of never dealing with this again.
Posts.Title: Help us understand options and risks marrt mdg

Posts.Content: Mar 29, 2015 09:54PM mdg wrote: I personally used caps but have two friends that did not use caps and also never got normal hair back after taxotere.  Not all ladies have this issue, but the occurrence of permanent hair thinning and loss is higher than the doctors tell you.  Both of my friends have bald spots and hair that is super thin and will not grow long at all.  Both are devastated.  I do have to add there are tons of ladies here that had taxotere and did not have permanent hair loss. The hard part is you just don't know how your own hair will respond.

Posts.Content: Jul 7, 2011 04:31PM mdg wrote: I have wondered some of the same things too.  I took the chemo despite being stage 1 because I had angiolymphatic invasion but clear nodes.  I felt like the cells had pathway to travel by blood established and I was scared they were just running through my body.  One med onc said the tammi would take care of them.  The other med onc suggested chemo because of angiolymphatic invasion and age and my overall health.  I hope the chemo did it's job.....I hope the tammi does it's job too. Through all of my diagnosis and treatments, not one doctor has used the word "curable".  They always say "treatable"......even with stage 1.  I really don't think they know...it's all "hocus pocus" in a way.....I had also wished there were studies about women with stage 1 that had done BMLX and chemo - you know, more specific to my situation.  Sometimes the studies include many types of patients so it's hard to understand what the stats really could be for you personally.  I guess in the end the stats don't matter and niether do the odds....someone always gets cancer or recurs.  1 in 8 gets BC and I was the 1 in 8........  I have less than a 10% chance of recurrence they tell me, but someone is always in that 10%...you never know who will be in the minority.......UGH!  BC stinks!

Posts.Content: Dec 3, 2011 11:27AM mdg wrote: I am sorry about your diagnosis.  It is sucky!!!  Period!  We are all angry at times and it is certainly and inconvenience but you have to get through it.  I am 46 and my son is only 5.  I was DX last December.  I am at the end of my treatment now and it has been a long year, but it gets better.  I have my last surgery this week.  I was able to keep a pretty normal schedule with my son through all of this other than chemo days and right after surgery.  It was not as bad as I thought it would be.  I used cold caps to keep my hair through chemo so now that I am done, I am just moving on with my life with my hair in tact.  As far as your appointments, meet with the oncologist, breast surgeon and plastic surgeon.  Even if you don't plan on a mastectomy, meet with plastics and know your options.  Ask about recurrence rates for lump+ rads vs mastectomy.  Survival rates are about the same.  Get a copy of your pathology report from your biopsy and lumpectomy or MX and understand what everything means on there.  That will help you know what questions to ask.  Get a notebook and write down what your doctors say...have someone go with you and take notes.   Take it one step at a time.  THe beginning is the worst part.  Somehow it gets easier when you get into treatment and start getting things going.  I am glad you have a support system..>I am Italian.  I get it!  :)

Posts.Content: Sep 18, 2011 05:19PM mdg wrote: I am so sorry you have become a member of the club no one wants to join.  The biopsy will tell you the type of tumor - hormone receptor positive or negative.  It will also tell what grade the tumor is - meaning how quick growing the cells are (this is different than the stage).  They can guess about the stage based on the size of tumor and by looking at your breast/lymph nodes by ultrasound but the only way to see if it is in the nodes for sure is by sentinel node biopsy.  You are at the worst part of all of this....the waiting for information part.  It is horrible.....not knowing what your treatment path is is agonizing.  The next several weeks will be filled with dr appts and waiting for test results.  Sometimes the complete diagnosis can change after surgery.  After my surgery I found out there was another small invasive area that was different than the tumor they found.  As far as treatment....it really depends on so many things.  It depends on the grade of the tumor, size of tumor, if it is mulit focal or not, location of tumor (if near chest wall they radiate), etc......Right now you have to wait until the tests are done.  I would ask your surgeon about a sentinel node biopsy and oncotype dx test.  You will also need to discuss your surgical options - mastecomy or lumpectomy and the recurrence rates for both.  The beginning was the hardest part for me.  I am sorry you have to deal with this too.  Hugs!

Posts.Title: Just diagnosed...what about ovaries TeriR Deirdre1

Posts.Content: May 24, 2011 05:06PM mdg wrote: I have the same diagnosis with those.  If you are ER/PR positive it means that your BC is dependent on estrogen to grow.  That usually means treatment with something like Tamoxifen for 5 years which is an estrogen blocker.  I will be starting Tamoxifen this week (I already did surgery and chemo).  If you are HER2 - it means you do not respond to a medicine called herceptin so that won't be a treatment for you.   HER2 + means the cancer is a bit more aggressive (from what I read - which is limited as I was HER2-).  Once you have surgery (lumpectomy or MX) the final pathology report  will help them with staging of your treatment.  Did they mention what grade you are?  (grade 1, 2 or 3).
