Posts.Content: Jan 29, 2011 02:14PM mdg wrote: I am home from my surgery.  Glad it is over with.  Surgery was on Thursday at 1pm.  It was a long morning...waiting for surgery for hours.  I listened to some really calming zhen type music on the ipod all morning and it really helped keep me from crying.  Surgery took about 5 hours.  TE were placed with 125cc in them.  I was suppose to go home the next day but had too much nausea and couldn't keep food down so I stayed until this morning.  I got home a few hours ago and am in bed.  My best friend came from out of state to care for me - she's a nurse for a surgical onc for breast surgery so I am in good care.  Things are sore, but less sore than I thought it would be.  I am feeling pretty OK.  For those of you going on Monday, good luck.  It's not that bad....really!  Anyone starting their exercises yet?
Posts.Title: January 2011 Mastectomy ibcmets SuebeeBC

Posts.Content: Jan 30, 2011 03:03PM mdg wrote: OK ladies....I am moving around today.  I got up and had a bath (From the waste down) which felt great.  I put a cut a hole in a plastic garbage bag and put my head through it - put a towel around my neck and secured it with a hair clip and got my hair washed while in the tub (my friend washed my hair).  I even shaved my legs in the tub.  It felt so good!  I was able to blow dry my hair too.  I went downstairs and had lunch on the couch with my mom.  I even had a little make up on!  I slept pretty well last night.  I woke up to go to the bathroom and take another pain pill then back to slep ti 7am this morning.  Overall, I am doing really well.  I am able to lift my arms over head (not straight up yet) pretty easy and I don't have to prop my arms on pillows anymore.  I am just shocked at how quickly I am feeling so good.  I can say what has helped I think is the fact that I do workout.  I have had to use a lot of core abdomingal muscles to get up and down and strong legs to get up/down from tub/toilet.  I said to my friend caring for me "I don't know how people do this if they are not in shape - it's a workout for sure".   I just wanted to send big, caring hugs to Super Sally, Redskyatnight and Dmho!  Honestly, the best things I did to help was using calming, zen music pre/post op to keep me calm. Taking pain meds every 4 hours around the clock to keep pain away, drinking lots of water.  I feel really good.  You ladies will do great!  OK - can we talk poop?   Is anyone pooping yet?  Good lord!  I have not gone since Thursday morning and I have been taking stool softeners and such since Friday.  I can't possible eat any more food until I go!  I feel like my stomach is distended and solid.  I keep eating high fiber food too..bean soup, salad, etc.....Please tell me the tummy will start moving again soon!
Posts.Title: January 2011 Mastectomy ibcmets SuebeeBC

Posts.Content: Feb 4, 2011 11:26AM mdg wrote: Hey ladies - just checking in.  8 day post BLMX and TE and drains are gone!  I had them out yesterday....I had to keep them 2 extra days because of the darn blizzard!  I didn't feel that bad with them in, I just feel better now!  I am feeling like my old self again today...my husband left me home alone for the first time since surgery!  (I feel like a teenager being left alone for the first time at home!).  I took a bath, washed my hair in the kitchen sink, blowdried and styled my hair (just like normal!!!!) and put my make up on.  I am not in sweats or jammies.......jeans and a fitted sweater.   My pre surgery A+ size is not that far off from what I have now.  I don't think anyone would even notice in my tank/fitted sweater that I am smaller.  I don't feel self conscious at all even in fitted clothes which shocks me.  I have 135 cc's in each TE.  I guess it would be more noticeable if I had been bigger before.  I am done with the pain meds too and they were killing my stomach so that is a relief.  I did take one yesterday before getting the drains out just in case (the nurse recommended that).  It made me so sick that I could barely eat all day.  I am pain med free today and starving.  Going to make myself some lunch right now and chow!  I have been doing the shoulder rolls, shoulder shrugs and lifting arms over head carefully.  It feels better each day....wondering how it will feel after some fills though.  Glad to hear everyone is through surgery!  Woo Hoo!!!  Now we are all on the mend.  Who's starting chemo next month.....anyone?  TC X4 for me....ICK!!!!!  That seems worse than the surgery.  I am thinking about doing cold caps to keep my hair.  Anyone else????

Posts.Content: Feb 24, 2011 08:41PM mdg wrote: My skin got sensitive about 2 weeks post op.  It feels like when my shirt moves against my chest that the skin is chaffed or raw feeling.  I found if I wore something fitted under my shirt it helped a little.  I wore a lot of tank tops with a shelf bra in them or just a fitted tank so there was less chance of fabric brushing against my chest as I move around.  My PS nurse said to take a dry washcloth and gently rub it accross my chest a few times a day to help the skin not be over sensitive.  I do forget but I always do a wet wash cloth each day in the shower and it seems to be getting better now and this week I will be 4 weeks post op.

Posts.Content: Mar 1, 2011 10:49PM mdg wrote: Renee:  I am sorry that the story seems to change as you go through this.  I was forced to make the choice on the chemo as one med onc said yes and the other said no.  My oncotype was not helpful....scored at 17 which is the highest number in the low group.  I am starting chemo tomorrow.  I too have a young child - my son is 4.  I am fortunate to have family and friends nearby.  Where do you live?  It would be cool if you were near me.  I could help you and would.  Supersally:  I did get my port last Wednesday.  It is ok.  I did get it in my arm.  I am glad I will not have one more scar in my chest area.  I went to the gym today in a tank top with my IPod holder on my arm near the port.  It was not noticeable really so I am cool with it.  Since it is winter here it is easy to hide in long sleeves.  You don't even see it.  Even with short sleeves, if your arms are down, no one would see it.  It is on the inside of my upper arm about half way down the bicep part of my arm.  Unless you really lift your arms, no one would see it.  I can still wear cute tank tops and not have it buldging in my chest near my collar bone.  My sis is a chemo infusion nurse and she suggested I get it in the arm. My PS is picky and did not want it in my chest at all so I am glad it's in my arm.  I took a photo a few days ago.  If you want to see, PM your email address.  You can see what it looks like - I have to warn you, the bruise is ugly, but is almost gone now.

Posts.Content: Feb 21, 2011 08:25PM mdg wrote: DMHO....good luck on your surgery.  I hope it leaves you healthy!  You have been through so much and I hope you get some relaxation and a little peace after this surgery.  If you can step into a jog bra or get one over your head, I found some Fruit of the Loom thin strap fitness bras (they have a spaghetti strap - about as thick as a thinner bra strap) at Walmart.  They are 3 for $10. Posts.Content: Mar 3, 2011 09:05PM mdg wrote: renmars:  I wish we were closer..I would help you in a heart beat.  THe caps work by cooling the scalp so the hair follicles don't get chemo and the hair does not fall out.  Most people will lose the other body hair but keep it on the head.  The success rates are different depending on the type of chemo you get.  It has good success with taxotere and cytoxan which is what I am on.  As far as discussing chemo with my son, I haven't said too much.  He knows a month ago I had a boo boo removed from my chest.  He didn't ask more questions.  He knows I would be sore for a while and have to rest.  In a week after surgery when I was in regular clothes with make up on and looking like me, he said "Mommy, I am so proud of you - you are all better".  He does not see me as sick.  I have not said much about chemo because I don't plan on losing my hair.  I did tell him that I spent the whole day at the doctors yesterday getting special medicines.  He asked if daddy was with me and I said yes.  I figure if I do have tired days, I will just tell him it's from the special medicines and I will feel better in a few days.  We have never had to mention the "C" word - we just keep it simple and explain it in a way that is on his level and ask if he has any questions....People say you only need to tell them what they want to know....so far, he is fine with everything we have told him.  I guess he feels secure.  We will see how the coming weeks go.  I had the oncotype too...I hope yours is SUPER low!  Sending LOW vibes your way.... Rennasus:  We are BC birthday twins!?!?  I am glad you enjoyed the blog.....it's my release right now of all the things I can't say in front of the people I love....

Posts.Content: May 2, 2011 07:38AM mdg wrote: First of all I am so sorry about your diagnosis...it does feel like a bad dream (I have been living it since December so I know!).  Hugs! Get your test results sent to your PCP and gyno.  That will keep your current doc's informed.  Don't be surprised if they call you..both of mine did to check up on me and talk with me (which was so nice).  They are not so involved in my care at all, but you will want them knowing all that is going on. The BS will not be the second opinion (I don't think) because he/she is the specialist that will just do your surgery (MX or lumpectomy).  I would however suggest meeting with more than one breast surgeon just to see what they say and to find the one you feel most comfortable with as they will be handling your care.  I saw 2 breast surgeons - both were at national cancer institutes.  As far as resources....if you have a local cancer center they can put you in touch with everything.  If not, ask your surgeon for information/referrals for information.  I personally did not pursue a support group right away as I was too scared to hear worse stories than my diagnosis -so keep that in mind.  I was Stage 1 and was just not ready to hear the stories emotionally from patients with more advanced situations as I was having huge anxiety about my own situation.  I have chosen to do online support here which has been great.  I am also starting counseling to just help get through the rest of this.  I would also look into seeing a plastic surgeon.  If you do need to consider having a MX they can help you understand your choices.  I met with PS's from the start to weigh out all my options.  Again - I met with 2 PS's from national cancer institutes.  Get copies of your reports, scans, mammo's and full pathology report.  You will want to start a file and have it with you. When you get our pathology report, read it completely and understand everything on there.   That will help you formulate good questions for your surgeons.   Best of luck!  Hugs!

Posts.Content: Nov 24, 2014 12:08PM mdg wrote: I am so sorry you have joined our group.....it is not fun but at least here you will find support and understanding.  My HER2 came back inconclusive at first and then they did the FISH test and it came back negative.  I wondered the same thing if it was good or bad before I had the results.  The good news is there have been new medications out recently that significantly help HER2 + breast cancer so if it comes back positive, there are more options.  When I was dx all of it seemed like a bad dream.....I know it just doesn't seem real. I do want to tell you that almost 4 years later, life has returned to normal and I feel great.  You will have a long year now, but get through it and then you can move forward and find the new normal.  I also had a bilateral mastectomy and chemo.  None of it is fun, but it is doable.  Just take all of this one step at a time.  Take a deep breath! Sending hugs!

Posts.Content: Jan 31, 2011 07:38PM mdg wrote: Hey Ladies, I am recovering well (surg was on Thurs).  I am going to call about drains tomorrow as today I will be less than 30cc per side.  Maybe they can come out!  I am hopeful.  Left drain I can't feel at all.  Right drain is a bit sore.  I am really feeling pretty good.  I still take the pain meds but not every 4 hours...I let it lapse a bit and it's been fine.  Quite honestly the poop was the worst issue....laxitives, enema, suposetorie, stool softeners.....so grosss.  I was up all night on the toilet and my poor DH had to go to the pharmacy twice in the middle of the night.  I have not been able to sleep all day yet....yes, I have been up since 4am last night.  I did lay around in bed and try to sleep, but no luck.  I am not usually a napper at all and never even really napped even when I was pregnant.  I had insomnia when I was pregnant...Oh well.  I feel good despite no sleep. I laid in bed and watched movies and talked with my best friend who has been here caring for me.  That has been the best part...having her here!  I am so bummed she is going home tomorrow :(  We have a major snow storm coming (ten inches I think) and she has a 5 hour drive home.  I will be lonely without her here!  My Dh has been a trooper.  My son has been so gentle with me with only gentle kisses on my face in lieu of his normal big monster hugs.  I feel much better than I anticipated.  I have been so blessed with kindess from family and friends and have had meals delivered for my family every day.  I have flowers, candy, cookies, snacks, care packages, fleece blankets, music and more.  I can't believe how much everyone is taking care of me.  I am going to start on thank you notes tomorrow....that should keep me busy for the next few days.   How are the post OP exercises going?  I have been doing the few I can do (most I can't start until drains come out) and I try to do them an hour or so after my pain meds were taken.  That makes it so much easier.  I don't do as well when the pain meds run out.  Min - sounds like you are doing well!  I am glad!  Still saying prayers for our few gals that had surgery today...waiting for news on them.

Posts.Content: Feb 1, 2011 03:55PM mdg wrote: Hey Ladies!  I am 5 days out and feeling good.  I have been taking a bath every day (waist down) and washing my hair every other day.  I even am able to blow dry it - which I was suprised.  My drains are less than 30cc daily but due to the major storm coming in, I think I will have to keep them for a few more days.  Am I the only one not having pain from the drains?  The right one was a little tender, but now that we learned how to tape it in position, I don't feel it at all.  I haven't even felt the left drain at all...don't even know it's there!  I actually put a regular - over the head shirt on today over my camisole that holds the drains.  I am able to do the shoulder rolls, reach over head, etc.....  I am still taking some pain meds but am going to lessen that today and see how I do.  I have still been taking ambien at night and have slept for at least a 6 or 7 hour block of time without waking at all.  The pooping issue was the WORST part of my surgery and recovery so far!  Things are getting more normal - thank the Lord!  My chest has one smaller bruise on one side...no real brusing and not really very swollen.  I look a little pale and feel tired but just can't nap so I am laying around a lot in front of the TV which is helping keep me rested.  My little boy has been avoiding me a little...think he's a little scared.  When he does come by me he is gentle and gives me sweet kisses on the cheek.  He asked me last night when we can hug again....broke my heart.  I said "really soon - I promise".  My best friend (onc nurse) has been here with me since I got home from the hospital.  Due to the major winter storm coming she had to go home (she lives out of state).  I cried for a long time after she left....I miss her so much and she was such a great help to us.  It was emotionally good having her here.  For now I am just trying to get back to something that resembles "normal" soon.  I am sick of laying around and being on pain meds.  I go back to the med onc on Thursday...chemo decision to make which is hard.  I really feel good - way better than I ever imagined.    Redsky....so sorry.  I was thinking about you all day yesterday....I hope you can get better quick and get that surgery over with!  I can tell you I feel really good at only 5 days out!  I hope our other girls having surgery yesterday did OK.......thinking of them!

Posts.Content: Sep 17, 2011 03:59PM mdg wrote: I have been blogging my BC journey since it started in early December.  I had BMX and reconstruction in addition to chemo.  I did not need radiation.  If the nodes are clear and the tumor is not close to the chest wall - since she is having a BMX she most likely won't need radiation.  Radiation will slow things down and delay reconstruction too.  I am 9 mo's post diagnosis and things seem more normal.  I am still scared at times but I have accepted my situation as best as I can and am trying to move on and live my life the best I can every day.  Hugs to your sister and your family.  I know how hard this is.  Good luck!

Posts.Content: Feb 8, 2011 01:12PM mdg wrote: Cindy - good for you on the drains be gone!  It is freeing!  I too have had a little back discomfort.  Once you can shower, that helps a bit...I have been taking some long, hot showers and that relaxes me.  The exercises help too.  One thing I realized is that since we have TE in the front, the chest muscles will tighten up and pull your posture forward and rounded over a bit.  To counter act that, you need to stretch the pecs (chest muscles) by contracting the upper back muscles (pulling shoulders back).  Ask your docs about this.  I am not recommending anyone do anything their doc isn't ok with.  My doc has me doing these among other exercises.  I just started an exercise check in thread for us Jan gals.

Posts.Content: Nov 10, 2014 02:34PM mdg wrote: Sunny I also wondered the same things and I started doing a lot of reading.  I will never know the answer to the "why me?" or "what did I eat/do?" questions.  I am almost 4 years out from my dx and I wonder a lot less the more time goes on.  The books I found helpful for me to move forward in a way that would allow me to minimize cancer causing foods were:  The Anti Cancer:  A New Way of Life and another book called Foods That Fight Cancer.  Both talk about how some of the differences in the foods the US consumes and how there are inflammatory properties in certain foods.  I have drastically changed my diet since reading the books.  Is it a guarantee BC won't come back?  No....but I feel like I am trying to do what I think is right.  I am all organic and I don't use harmful chemicals.  When I started reading what was in beauty care products, I went to my bathroom and read all the labels....that resulted in a HUGE garbage bag full of almost everything I had.  I have slowly replaced my health and beauty products and make up with things that are more natural.  Some people think I am crazy for adopting such changes, but I look at it this way.....I was healthy before with no family history.  I was a fitness professional for over 20 years and exercised a lot.  My body still grew BC.  Knowing that my body can and does do this, I avoid anything with hormones, hormonal properties, chemicals, etc.....  Clearly my body is sensitive to something.  I also added yoga to my workouts and quit my high stress job to bring more peace into my life.  Yes, my life has done a 180 degree change, but for me life is much better now than before BC. I am in no way telling people to do the extreme things I did.  Each person has to make their own decisions and do what they feel is right for them.  This was what I felt was right for me after my dx.

Posts.Content: Oct 26, 2011 09:05AM mdg wrote: I also had LVI and an oncotype score of 17.  I was 45 at DX.  The rest of my stats are below.  I was told by one med onc no chemo. The other one said I would benefit from it.  My tumor was grade 2.  I had to decide.  I decided on chemo for a few reasons: 1.  My son was only 4 and I wanted to do everything I could physically do to be here for him. 2.  I was already doing an aggressive BMX so why skip chemo 3.  I was concerned if for some odd reason I could not tolerate tamoxifen I would regret not doing chemo 4.  LVI  - this weighed heavily in my mind that there was a pathway established that the cancer could have already spread by blood My med onc had me do TCx4.  It was not that bad.  I used cold caps to keep my hair.  I am almost 6 mo's post chemo now and am glad I did it.  I know I have done everything available to me to try to beat this.  I have been on tamoxifen since June and other than hot flashes I am tolerating it well.

Posts.Content: Feb 5, 2011 09:22AM mdg wrote: As far as exercise...I would love to by my PS said no.  It is freezing here so I went to the mall...good, warm place to walk around.  I assured my PS it would only be leisure walking and he was cool with that.  If it's too cold by you...head to the mall.  Leave your credit cards at home so you won't be tempted.....I didn't even buy anything!  I can't drive yet so my friend took me.  It was nice to walk around and talk.  I felt really good after that yesterday!  I am only doing shoulder rolls, shoulder shrugs and reaching a little over head.  I hope to start the rest of the exercises in the book I got from the Breast Cancer Center after I see my PS on Monday.  About the cording...after my lumpectomy and SNB I had tightness in from my chest down into my arm.  It did last a about a month but then was gone (it got better gradually).  I did do stretching and exercising.  I was back to doing my regular exercise routine (weights, aerobics) a few weeks post lump/SNB.  That really helped I think.  I don't know how long it would take or what exercises will be appropriate post MX though.  If you have the cording feeling, can you see if you can see a physical therapist?  If you have an Rx for it from your surgeon, your insurance should cover it.  Just a suggestion......I hope it gets better!

Posts.Content: Feb 23, 2011 09:02PM mdg wrote: DMHO - I am glad you are home, but feel so bad you have had to go through so much.  Let your body rest now...if you need sleep, do it.  Eat well and keep up on the water too.  That will all help your body get stronger.   I have not had the lack of energy you gals have had, but then again when under stress I never sleep.  I am the girl who had insomnia the entire time I was pregnant and only took 2 naps while pregnant (eventhough I was on complete bedrest for my third trimester!).  I have only napped once since coming home from the hospital (the first day) from my BLMX.  I tried ambien so I could sleep at night and it did not work.  I take xanax before bed and probably get 6-7 hours of sleep a night max.  I feel tired in the morning when the alarm goes off to get my son up for school, but then I am up and start my day.  Some days I wish I could nap.....sounds nice but I never fall asleep so why try.  Today I got my chemo port in.....I had it placed in my arm as my PS did not want it in my chest at all.  I did not know I was going to be awake for this procedure.....that freaked me out when they told me that.  I was awake the whole time....didn't feel pain just some pressure or poking here and there. Posts.Content: Feb 15, 2012 01:04PM mdg wrote: Carrie, We have similar stats.  My tumor was the same size as yours.  I was 45 last year when DX and had clear nodes.  My oncotype was 17.  The problem was that I had angiolymphatic invasion present in my pathology meaning there was potential for the cancer to spread by blood.  I did do a BMX to be aggressive but my doctors were on the fence on chemo and left the choice to me.  I was also told I would have TCx4 and was more scared about chemo than the BMX!  I opted for the chemo.  It was not as bad as I thought.  I did cold caps to keep my hair and it worked for me.  I had a few tired days after each chemo.  I never took any meds for nausea...didn't have any.  I exercised 5 days a week through all of chemo...never missed a workout other than infusion days.  I did have some side effects but I am glad I did it.  I have a young son and wanted to know that I had done everything possible to kick this.  Best of luck with your decision. I agonized over to do chemo or not...I know how hard it is.  Hugs!
Posts.Title: Another "Chemo or No Chemo?" Dilemma! crking71 bcisnofun

Posts.Content: Dec 28, 2010 05:31PM mdg wrote: Thanks ladies; Jan - I was not scheduled for the lumpectomy at all.  I went in for SNB and the tumor was right there near the SNB area so my surgeon just took it out eventhough he knew we were doing BLMX.  He figured it would give us more information and that would be good for me.  I was glad he took it out.  As of now, I guess that makes me cancer free technically, right?  It's a step in the right direction.
